simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-07T16:12:18.000Z ##

Cisco security advisories:

  • ClamAV OLE2 File Format Parsing Denial of Service Vulnerability
    CVE-2024-20290 (7.5 high)
  • Cisco Expressway Series Cross-Site Request Forgery Vulnerabilities
    CVE-2024-20252, CVE-2024-20254, CVE-2024-20255 (9.6 critical)
    • Note: Cisco's own URL in advisory is missing 'csrf' which is a broken link. Please use https://sec.cloudapps.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-expressway-csrf-KnnZDMj3

The Cisco PSIRT is not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities that are described in these advisories.

#Cisco #PatchTuesday #vulnerability #securityadvisory #ClamAV #CiscoExpressway

##

CVE-2024-21888
(8.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.05%

5 posts

A privilege escalation vulnerability in web component of Ivanti Connect Secure (9.x, 22.x) and Ivanti Policy Secure (9.x, 22.x) allows a user to elevate privileges to that of an administrator.

jschauma@mstdn.social at 2024-02-08T21:44:52.000Z ##

Oh man, Ivanti is going for the full list of attack vectors, huh?

First we got the auth-bypass (CVE-2023-46805) and the command-injection (CVE-2024-21887), then we added privilege-escalation (CVE-2024-21888) and an SSRF (CVE-2024-21893), and today we get CVE-2024-22024, an XXE vulnerability in their SAML that provides unauth'd access to some components.

https://forums.ivanti.com/s/article/CVE-2024-22024-XXE-for-Ivanti-Connect-Secure-and-Ivanti-Policy-Secure?language=en_US

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-05T15:10:37.000Z ##

@wdormann I have to disagree here. Ivanti created a new advisory (originally created 22 January for logged in Ivanti customers, and made public on 31 January) https://forums.ivanti.com/s/article/CVE-2024-21888-Privilege-Escalation-for-Ivanti-Connect-Secure-and-Ivanti-Policy-Secure?language=en_US , and updated both the blog https://www.ivanti.com/blog/security-update-for-ivanti-connect-secure-and-ivanti-policy-secure-gateways and the older advisory from 10 January https://forums.ivanti.com/s/article/CVE-2023-46805-Authentication-Bypass-CVE-2024-21887-Command-Injection-for-Ivanti-Connect-Secure-and-Ivanti-Policy-Secure-Gateways?language=en_US which everyone was following for updates.

##
avolha@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-02T21:18:25.000Z ##

Parę słów o tym, dlaczego CISA dała amerykańskim agencjom federalnym tylko 48 godz. na uporanie się z lukami w VPN-ach firmy Ivanti. Otóż luki pozwalające przejąć nad nimi kontrolę dodała do swego arsenału wspierana przez chiński rząd grupa APT, którą Volexity identyfikuje jako UTA0178, a Mandiant jako UNC5221.

Ataki zaczęły się na początku grudnia i przybrały charakter globalny (przejęte urządzenia znajdują się też w Polsce, choć w porównaniu z USA niewiele). W styczniu badacze przeanalizowali wykorzystanie CVE-2023-46805 i CVE-2024-21887. Pierwsza z wymienionych luk pozwala na ominięcie uwierzytelniania. Druga umożliwia wstrzyknięcie dowolnego polecenia w panelu webowym takich urządzeń, jak Ivanti Connect Secure i Ivanti Policy Secure. Atakujący posłużyli się nimi, by wykraść dane, za pomocą których logowali się później do wewnętrznych systemów przez RDP/SMB/SSH.

Ledwo Ivanti wydało stosowne poprawki, wykryto jeszcze dwie luki. CVE-2024-21888 umożliwia podniesienie poziomu uprawnień, a CVE-2024-21893 jest błędem po stronie serwera, który daje dostęp do określonych zasobów bez uwierzytelniania. Drugą z wymienionych luk zainteresowali się już przestępcy.

Analizy Volexity:
1. https://www.volexity.com/blog/2024/01/10/active-exploitation-of-two-zero-day-vulnerabilities-in-ivanti-connect-secure-vpn/
2. https://www.volexity.com/blog/2024/01/15/ivanti-connect-secure-vpn-exploitation-goes-global/
3. https://www.volexity.com/blog/2024/01/18/ivanti-connect-secure-vpn-exploitation-new-observations/
4. https://www.volexity.com/blog/2024/02/01/how-memory-forensics-revealed-exploitation-of-ivanti-connect-secure-vpn-zero-day-vulnerabilities/

Analizy Mandianta:
1. https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/suspected-apt-targets-ivanti-zero-day
2. https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/investigating-ivanti-zero-day-exploitation

#infosec #cyberbezpieczenstwo #ivanti

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-02T17:37:38.000Z ##

@wdormann watchTowr reports additional zero-days discovered while trying to reproduce the Ivanti CVEs CVE-2024-21888 and CVE-2024-21893:
https://twitter.com/watchtowrcyber/status/1753366975609475472

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-01T20:22:13.000Z ##

@dangoodin Patch testing takes time to ensure that threat actors don't figure out a way to bypass the patch, which would then be in itself a new zero-day (when someone other than the vendor knows an existing vulnerability). During their continued investigation and patch testing, they discovered CVE-2024-21888, which they stated "We have no evidence of customers being impacted by CVE-2024-21888 at this time" and CVE-2024-21893 (We are only aware of a small number of customers who have been impacted by CVE-2024-21893 at this time.)

The patch they released for about 7 versions of products (Ivanti Connect Secure (versions 9.1R14.4, 9.1R17.2, 9.1R18.3, 22.4R2.2, 22.5R1.1 and 22.5R2.2), Ivanti Policy Secure version 22.5R1.1 and ZTA version 22.6R1.3) fix all four vulnerabilities instead of hotfixing two and needing additional patches. "CVE-2023-46805, CVE-2024-21887, CVE-2024-21888, and CVE-2024-21893 are all remediated with the patch."

I can't believe I'm defending Ivanti but rushing a patch would have been worse.

##

CVE-2023-47568
(8.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.05%

1 posts

A SQL injection vulnerability has been reported to affect several QNAP operating system versions. If exploited, the vulnerability could allow authenticated users to inject malicious code via a network. We have already fixed the vulnerability in the following versions: QTS 5.1.5.2645 build 20240116 and later QTS 4.5.4.2627 build 20231225 and later QuTS hero h5.1.5.2647 build 20240118 and later QuT

avoidthehack@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-05T16:20:00.000Z ##

#QNAP Patches High-Severity Bugs in QTS, Qsync Central

High severity OS command #injection flaws ( CVE-2023-45025 and CVE-2023-39297) found in some QNAP devices.

Also two remotely exploitable flaws (OS command injections and SQL injection) tracked as CVE-2023-47567 and CVE-2023-47568.

According to QNAP, no evidence these vulnerabilities have been exploited in the wild.

If you have a device, you should update ASAP!

#cybersecurity #cve #security #update

https://www.securityweek.com/qnap-patches-high-severity-bugs-in-qts-qsync-central/

##

CVE-2024-20252
(9.6 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.05%

5 posts

Multiple vulnerabilities in Cisco Expressway Series and Cisco TelePresence Video Communication Server (VCS) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks that perform arbitrary actions on an affected device. Note: "Cisco Expressway Series" refers to Cisco Expressway Control (Expressway-C) devices and Cisco Expressway Edge (Expressway-E) de

H3liumb0y at 2024-02-08T08:59:29.905Z ##

"🚨 Cisco Expressway Gateways under CSRF Attack Siege! 🚨"

Cisco has addressed severe vulnerabilities in its Expressway Series, notably two critical CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) flaws, CVE-2024-20252 and CVE-2024-20254. These vulnerabilities could let unauthenticated attackers remotely trick authenticated users into executing unintended actions by clicking malicious links or visiting attacker-controlled resources, like adding user accounts or gaining administrative privileges. A third bug, CVE-2024-20255 can potentially trigger configuration alterations and denial of service attacks. The company won't provide security updates for the Cisco TelePresence Video Communication Server (VCS) gateway due to reaching the end-of-support date on December 31, 2023, but for other devices still in support, Cisco advises users to upgrade to a fixed version for enhanced security. No active exploit attempts have been reported yet.

Credits: Cisco Security Advisory & BleepingComputer's article

Tags: #Cisco #Cybersecurity #CSRFVulnerability #InfoSec #NetworkSecurity #CSRF #CVE202420252 #CVE202420254 #CVE202420255

H3liumb0y@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-08T08:59:29.000Z ##

A third bug, CVE-2024-20255 can potentially trigger configuration alterations and denial of service attacks. The company won't provide security updates for the Cisco TelePresence Video Communication Server (VCS) gateway due to reaching the end-of-support date on December 31, 2023, but for other devices still in support, Cisco advises users to upgrade to a fixed version for enhanced security. ##

CVE-2024-20255
(8.2 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.05%

5 posts

A vulnerability in the SOAP API of Cisco Expressway Series and Cisco TelePresence Video Communication Server could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attack on an affected system. This vulnerability is due to insufficient CSRF protections for the web-based management interface of an affected system. An attacker could exploit this vulnerabili

H3liumb0y at 2024-02-08T08:59:29.905Z ##

"🚨 Cisco Expressway Gateways under CSRF Attack Siege! 🚨"

Cisco has addressed severe vulnerabilities in its Expressway Series, notably two critical CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) flaws, CVE-2024-20252 and CVE-2024-20254. These vulnerabilities could let unauthenticated attackers remotely trick authenticated users into executing unintended actions by clicking malicious links or visiting attacker-controlled resources, like adding user accounts or gaining administrative privileges. A third bug, CVE-2024-20255 can potentially trigger configuration alterations and denial of service attacks. The company won't provide security updates for the Cisco TelePresence Video Communication Server (VCS) gateway due to reaching the end-of-support date on December 31, 2023, but for other devices still in support, Cisco advises users to upgrade to a fixed version for enhanced security. No active exploit attempts have been reported yet.

Credits: Cisco Security Advisory & BleepingComputer's article

These vulnerabilities could let unauthenticated attackers remotely trick authenticated users into executing unintended actions by clicking malicious links or visiting attacker-controlled resources, like adding user accounts or gaining administrative privileges. A third bug, CVE-2024-20255 can potentially trigger configuration alterations and denial of service attacks. The company won't provide security updates for the Cisco TelePresence Video Communication Server (VCS) gateway due to reaching the end-of-support date on December 31, 2023, but for other devices still in support, Cisco advises users to upgrade to a fixed version for enhanced security. No active exploit attempts have been reported yet.

Credits: Cisco Security Advisory & BleepingComputer's article

Tags: #Cisco #Cybersecurity #CSRFVulnerability #InfoSec #NetworkSecurity #CSRF #CVE202420252 #CVE202420254 #CVE202420255

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-07T16:12:18.000Z ##

Cisco security advisories:

  • ClamAV OLE2 File Format Parsing Denial of Service Vulnerability
    CVE-2024-20290 (7.5 high)
  • Cisco Expressway Series Cross-Site Request Forgery Vulnerabilities
    CVE-2024-20252, CVE-2024-20254, CVE-2024-20255 (9.6 critical)
    • Note: Cisco's own URL in advisory is missing 'csrf' which is a broken link. Please use https://sec.cloudapps.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-expressway-csrf-KnnZDMj3

The Cisco PSIRT is not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities that are described in these advisories.

#Cisco #PatchTuesday #vulnerability #securityadvisory #ClamAV #CiscoExpressway

#QNAP Patches High-Severity Bugs in QTS, Qsync Central

High severity OS command #injection flaws ( CVE-2023-45025 and CVE-2023-39297) found in some QNAP devices.

CVE-2021-4034
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.05%

1 posts

A local privilege escalation vulnerability was found on polkit's pkexec utility. The pkexec application is a setuid tool designed to allow unprivileged users to run commands as privileged users according predefined policies. The current version of pkexec doesn't handle the calling parameters count correctly and ends trying to execute environment variables as commands. An attacker can leverage this

simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-05T16:32:45.000Z ##

Akamai provided details about a new variant of the FritzFrog botnet, which abuses the 2021 Log4Shell vulnerability CVE-2021-44228 (10.0 critical). The vulnerability is exploited in a brute-force manner that attempts to target as many vulnerable Java applications as possible. The malware also now also includes a module to exploit CVE-2021-4034, a privilege escalation in the polkit Linux component. This module enables the malware to run as root on vulnerable servers. IOC provided.
🔗 https://www.akamai.com/blog/security-research/2024/feb/fritzfrog-botnet-new-capabilities-log4shell

#FritzFrog #botnet #IOC #Log4Shell #CVE_2021_44228 #CVE_2021_4034 #threatintel #IOC

simontsui at 2024-02-13T15:32:35.979Z ##

Not exploited in the wild.

@campuscodi Unit 42 calls CVE-2023-50358 a zero day, says that exploitation attempts were made against it in the wild:

On Nov. 7, 2023, Unit 42 researchers were alerted of suspicious attack traffic targeted at QNAP devices by the Advanced Threat Prevention platform. Further analysis revealed a new vulnerability related to (but not directly exploited by) the observed traffic.

  • https://www.qnap.com/en/security-advisory/qsa-23-57

I'm not happy with the wording but the vulnerability was known by threat actors who attempted to exploit it. QNAP doesn't mention exploitation attempts or being aware of exploits in the wild.

CVE-2023-42282(CVSS UNKNOWN)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

An issue in all published versions of the NPM package `ip` allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code and obtain sensitive information via the `isPublic()` function. This can lead to potential Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) attacks. The core issue is the function's failure to accurately distinguish between public and private IP addresses.

thbley@phpc.social at 2024-02-12T19:59:37.000Z ##

IPv4 addresses may be represented in "any" notation expressing a 32-bit integer value.
CVE-2023-42282 https://github.com/indutny/node-ip/issues/136
- package has 22m downloads per week
- package is unmaintained for 2 years
Some IPv4 notations: https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/having-fun-ip-addresses-christian-luger/

CVE-2024-25728(CVSS UNKNOWN)

EPSS: 0.04%

2 posts

ExpressVPN before 12.73.0 on Windows, when split tunneling is used, sends DNS requests according to the Windows configuration (e.g., sends them to DNS servers operated by the user's ISP instead of to the ExpressVPN DNS servers), which may allow remote attackers to obtain sensitive information about websites visited by VPN users.

(8.0 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

Late privilege drop in REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW CONCURRENTLY in PostgreSQL allows an object creator to execute arbitrary SQL functions as the command issuer. The command intends to run SQL functions as the owner of the materialized view, enabling safe refresh of untrusted materialized views. The victim is a superuser or member of one of the attacker's roles. The attack requires luring the victim

CVE-2024-23448
(5.7 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

An issue was discovered whereby APM Server could log at ERROR level, a response from Elasticsearch indicating that indexing the document failed and that response would contain parts of the original document. Depending on the nature of the document that the APM Server attempted to ingest, this could lead to the insertion of sensitive or private information in the APM Server logs.

simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-07T01:49:48.000Z ##

Elastic security advisories:

  • Kibana 8.12.1 Security Update (ESA-2024-01)
    CVE-2024-23446 (5.0 medium) Kibana Broken Access Control issue
  • Elastic Network Drive Connector 8.12.1 Security Update (ESA-2024-02)
    CVE-2024-23447 (6.5 medium) Elastic Network Drive Connector Improper Access Control
  • APM Server 8.12.1 Security Update (ESA-2024-03)
    CVE-2024-23448 (5.7 medium) APM Server Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File

No mention of exploitation.

#Elastic #Kibana #vulnerability #PatchTuesday

##

CVE-2024-23447
(5.3 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

An issue was discovered in the Windows Network Drive Connector when using Document Level Security to assign permissions to a file, with explicit allow write and deny read. Although the document is not accessible to the user in Network Drive it is visible in search applications to the user.

simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-07T01:49:48.000Z ##

Elastic security advisories:

  • Kibana 8.12.1 Security Update (ESA-2024-01)
    CVE-2024-23446 (5.0 medium) Kibana Broken Access Control issue
  • Elastic Network Drive Connector 8.12.1 Security Update (ESA-2024-02)
    CVE-2024-23447 (6.5 medium) Elastic Network Drive Connector Improper Access Control
  • APM Server 8.12.1 Security Update (ESA-2024-03)
    CVE-2024-23448 (5.7 medium) APM Server Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File

No mention of exploitation.

#Elastic #Kibana #vulnerability #PatchTuesday

##

CVE-2024-23446
(6.5 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

An issue was discovered by Elastic, whereby the Detection Engine Search API does not respect Document-level security (DLS) or Field-level security (FLS) when querying the .alerts-security.alerts-{space_id} indices. Users who are authorized to call this API may obtain unauthorized access to documents if their roles are configured with DLS or FLS against the aforementioned index.

simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-07T01:49:48.000Z ##

Elastic security advisories:

  • Kibana 8.12.1 Security Update (ESA-2024-01)
    CVE-2024-23446 (5.0 medium) Kibana Broken Access Control issue
  • Elastic Network Drive Connector 8.12.1 Security Update (ESA-2024-02)
    CVE-2024-23447 (6.5 medium) Elastic Network Drive Connector Improper Access Control
  • APM Server 8.12.1 Security Update (ESA-2024-03)
    CVE-2024-23448 (5.7 medium) APM Server Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File

No mention of exploitation.

#Elastic #Kibana #vulnerability #PatchTuesday

##

CVE-2024-22238
(6.4 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

Aria Operations for Networks contains a cross site scripting vulnerability. A malicious actor with admin privileges may be able to inject malicious code into user profile configurations due to improper input sanitization.

simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-06T17:27:58.000Z ##

VMware security advisory for VMware Aria Operations for Networks. No mention of exploitation.

  • Local Privilege Escalation vulnerability CVE-2024-22237 (7.8 high)
  • Cross Site Scripting Vulnerability CVE-2024-22238 (6.4 medium)
  • Local Privilege Escalation vulnerability CVE-2024-22239 (5.3 medium)
  • Local File Read vulnerability CVE-2024-22240 (4.9 medium)
  • Cross Site Scripting vulnerability CVE-2024-22241 (4.3 medium)

🔗 https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2024-0002.html

#VMware #securityadvisory #vulnerability #PatchTuesday #Aria

##

CVE-2024-22241
(4.3 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

Aria Operations for Networks contains a cross site scripting vulnerability. A malicious actor with admin privileges can inject a malicious payload into the login banner and takeover the user account.  

simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-06T17:27:58.000Z ##

VMware security advisory for VMware Aria Operations for Networks. No mention of exploitation.

  • Local Privilege Escalation vulnerability CVE-2024-22237 (7.8 high)
  • Cross Site Scripting Vulnerability CVE-2024-22238 (6.4 medium)
  • Local Privilege Escalation vulnerability CVE-2024-22239 (5.3 medium)
  • Local File Read vulnerability CVE-2024-22240 (4.9 medium)
  • Cross Site Scripting vulnerability CVE-2024-22241 (4.3 medium)

🔗 https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2024-0002.html

#VMware #securityadvisory #vulnerability #PatchTuesday #Aria

##

CVE-2023-35116
(7.5 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

An issue was discovered jackson-databind thru 2.15.2 allows attackers to cause a denial of service or other unspecified impacts via crafted object that uses cyclic dependencies.

tallison@mastodon.social at 2024-02-05T22:14:23.000Z ##

@mistersql

##

CVE-2024-22237
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

Aria Operations for Networks contains a local privilege escalation vulnerability. A console user with access to Aria Operations for Networks may exploit this vulnerability to escalate privileges to gain root access to the system.

simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-06T17:27:58.000Z ##

  • Local Privilege Escalation vulnerability CVE-2024-22237 (7.8 high)
  • Cross Site Scripting Vulnerability CVE-2024-22238 (6.4 medium)
  • Local Privilege Escalation vulnerability CVE-2024-22239 (5.3 medium)

  • Cross Site Scripting vulnerability CVE-2024-22241 (4.3 medium)

#VMware #securityadvisory #vulnerability #PatchTuesday #Aria

##

CVE-2024-22239
(5.3 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

Aria Operations for Networks contains a local privilege escalation vulnerability. A console user with access to Aria Operations for Networks may exploit this vulnerability to escalate privileges to gain regular shell access.

simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-06T17:27:58.000Z ##

VMware security advisory for VMware Aria Operations for Networks. No mention of exploitation.

  • Local Privilege Escalation vulnerability CVE-2024-22237 (7.8 high)
  • Cross Site Scripting Vulnerability CVE-2024-22238 (6.4 medium)
  • Local Privilege Escalation vulnerability CVE-2024-22239 (5.3 medium)
  • Local File Read vulnerability CVE-2024-22240 (4.9 medium)
  • Cross Site Scripting vulnerability CVE-2024-22241 (4.3 medium)

🔗 https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2024-0002.html

#VMware #securityadvisory #vulnerability #PatchTuesday #Aria

##

CVE-2023-45779
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

In TBD of TBD, there is a possible malicious update to platform components due to improperly used crypto. This could lead to local escalation of privilege with no additional execution privileges needed. User interaction is not needed for exploitation.

1 repos

https://github.com/metaredteam/rtx-cve-2023-45779

jbhall56@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-01T13:08:55.000Z ##

Tracked as CVE-2023-45779, the flaw was discovered by Meta's Red Team X in early September 2023 and was addressed in Android's December 2023 security update without disclosing details an attacker could use to discern and exploit it. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/exploit-released-for-android-local-elevation-flaw-impacting-7-oems/

##

CVE-2014-0017(CVSS UNKNOWN)

EPSS: 0.04%

1 posts

The RAND_bytes function in libssh before 0.6.3, when forking is enabled, does not properly reset the state of the OpenSSL pseudo-random number generator (PRNG), which causes the state to be shared between children processes and allows local users to obtain sensitive information by leveraging a pid collision.

emaste@mastodon.social at 2024-01-31T22:30:01.000Z ##

@simondassow @gyptazy E.g. in a writeup for CVE-2014-0016 and CVE-2014-0017:

> OSes with sequential PID generation are then less vulnerable than OSes with random PID (AFAIK only OpenBSD).

https://blog.0xbadc0de.be/archives/218#more-218

##

CVE-2024-21451
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.00%

2 posts

N/A

jos1264@social.skynetcloud.site at 2024-02-13T20:55:04.000Z ##

jos1264@social.skynetcloud.site at 2024-02-13T20:55:04.000Z ##

##

CVE-2023-50387
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.00%

21 posts

N/A

tychotithonus at 2024-02-13T22:51:51.189Z ##

I have two posts about the new multi-implementation DNSSEC validation DoS vulnerabilities CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap") and CVE-2023-50868 (the NSEC3 vuln):

  • The big summary post (more editing - your client may notify you about each edit, which may be a feature):

https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111924626712765292

  • The post you're reading (low editing, minimal noise, but you might want to check the big post occasionally for updates).

#keytrap #nsec3 #CVE202350387 #CVE202350868 #CVE_2023_50387 #CVE_2023_50868
#dns #dnssec

##
tychotithonus at 2024-02-13T14:24:29.911Z ##

(living doc, updated regularly - if you prefer a low-edit post to boost, use https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111926621712441626)

Looks like DNS-OARC coordinated fixes in advance, but I don't see a centralized analysis, other than this announcement from the team who discovered KeyTrap:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap
(Details may be still partially embargoed until patching ramps up)?

Analysis:

DoS of all major DNS servers at the implementation level. Servers are also clients; not clear to me if endpoint clients are vulnerable, but servers clearly are. Exploitation described as 'trivial'. Both are CVSS 7.5. DNS is a rich ransom target - but some resolver setups don't even validate DNSSEC.

"In 2012 the vulnerability made its way into the implementation requirements for DNSSEC validation, standards RFC 6781 and RFC 6840" (per ATHENE)

Per the Unbound writeup, both vulns require query to a malicious zone (which is probably not hard to trigger, for any DNSSEC-enabled client or server).

Resolution: patch (recommended); disable DNSSEC validation (discouraged, but can buy you time / mitigate active DoS)

Fixes mitigate the exhaustion by putting caps on validation activities. These caps appear to have been missing from most implementations.

Details:

Two DNSSEC DoS CVEs:

CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap"): "DNSSEC verification complexity can be exploited to exhaust CPU resources and stall DNS resolvers" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125

(KeyTrap was discovered by ATHENE - their press release here has very important detail:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap)

CVE-2023-50868: "NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

MITRE links (CVEs reserved, no details yet):
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50387
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50868

Vulmon queries:
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50387
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50868

Patch status:

ISC BIND (patched - vuln since 2000?):
https://fosstodon.org/@iscdotorg/111924416653890048
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50387
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50868
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125
(note: posts say "Versions prior to 9.11.37 were not assessed." but also have a range of affected versions starting at 9.0.0 - typo?)

Unbound (patched - vuln since Aug 2007):
https://nlnetlabs.nl/news/2024/Feb/13/unbound-1.19.1-released/
https://nlnetlabs.nl/downloads/unbound/CVE-2023-50387_CVE-2023-50868.txt
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/126

dnsmasq (patched - 2.90 has fix):
https://thekelleys.org.uk/dnsmasq/CHANGELOG
https://lists.thekelleys.org.uk/pipermail/dnsmasq-discuss/2024q1/017430.html

Pi-Hole (uses dnsmasq - fixes in beta)
https://pi-hole.net/blog/2024/02/13/fixing-two-new-dnssec-vulnerabilities/

PowerDNS (patched - all versions affected):
https://blog.powerdns.com/2024/02/13/powerdns-recursor-4-8-6-4-9-3-5-0-2-released
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13781
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13784

OS status:

FreeBSD:
https://cgit.freebsd.org/ports/commit/?id=58e048cad653819eebf91af5840e4b00f155bb1b

Ubuntu:
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50387
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50868
https://ubuntu.com/security/notices/USN-6633-1

Windows (Server, DNS Role):
https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2023-50387

Package status:

BIND:
https://repology.org/project/bind/versions

dnsmasq:
https://repology.org/project/dnsmasq/versions

Unbound:
https://repology.org/project/unbound/versions

Non-coverage: (no mentions known yet)

Akamai
https://www.akamai.com/blog [?]

AWS
[?]

Azure (Microsoft Server DNS?)
[?]

Cisco Umbrella:
https://umbrella.cisco.com/blog [?]

Cloudflare
https://blog.cloudflare.com/ [?]

CoreDNS
https://coredns.io/blog/ [?]

Google DNS
[?]
(The Register article (see below) says Google is aware)

Infoblox
https://blogs.infoblox.com/ [?]

Quad9 DNS
https://www.quad9.net/news/blog/ [?]

Red Hat:
https://access.redhat.com/security/security-updates/cve [?]

News/Press

https://www.theregister.com/2024/02/13/dnssec_vulnerability_internet/

Validation:

Check to see if a server is doing DNSSEC validation (if not an open recursive resolver, you may need to query a zone the server is authoritative for):

# zone signed, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv example.net @8.8.8.8
; fully validated
example.net.            4437    IN      A       93.184.216.34
example.net.            4437    IN      RRSIG   A 13 2 86400 20240225232039 20240204162038 18113 example.net. 94G2PRXins1G9ntfklvCq2mvcgqjB0z9FqQXp77lD/wXR4J3D67ceih1 yNgsYYqlIAOoWKXUekux6Zq9aIwszQ==

# zone unsigned, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv google.com @8.8.8.8
; unsigned answer
google.com.             100     IN      A       142.250.69.206

Exploits:

(none yet known / public, but multiple sources describe as "trivial")

#keytrap #nsec3 #CVE202350387 #CVE202350868 #CVE_2023_50387 #CVE_2023_50868
#dns #dnssec

Vulmon queries:
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50387
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50868

Patch status:

ISC BIND (patched - vuln since 2000?):
https://fosstodon.org/@iscdotorg/111924416653890048
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50387
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50868
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125
(note: posts say "Versions prior to 9.11.37 were not assessed." but also have a range of affected versions starting at 9.0.0 - typo?)

Unbound (patched - vuln since Aug 2007):
https://nlnetlabs.nl/news/2024/Feb/13/unbound-1.19.1-released/
https://nlnetlabs.nl/downloads/unbound/CVE-2023-50387_CVE-2023-50868.txt
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/126

dnsmasq (patched - 2.90 has fix):
https://thekelleys.org.uk/dnsmasq/CHANGELOG
https://lists.thekelleys.org.uk/pipermail/dnsmasq-discuss/2024q1/017430.html

Pi-Hole (uses dnsmasq - fixes in beta)
https://pi-hole.net/blog/2024/02/13/fixing-two-new-dnssec-vulnerabilities/

PowerDNS (patched - all versions affected):
https://blog.powerdns.com/2024/02/13/powerdns-recursor-4-8-6-4-9-3-5-0-2-released
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13781
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13784

OS status:

FreeBSD:
https://cgit.freebsd.org/ports/commit/?id=58e048cad653819eebf91af5840e4b00f155bb1b

Ubuntu:
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50387
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50868
https://ubuntu.com/security/notices/USN-6633-1

Windows (Server, DNS Role):
https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2023-50387

Package status:

BIND:
https://repology.org/project/bind/versions

dnsmasq:
https://repology.org/project/dnsmasq/versions

Unbound:
https://repology.org/project/unbound/versions

Non-coverage: (no mentions known yet)

Akamai
https://www.akamai.com/blog [?]

[?]

Azure (Microsoft Server DNS?)
[?]

Cisco Umbrella:
https://umbrella.cisco.com/blog [?]

Cloudflare
https://blog.cloudflare.com/ [?]

CoreDNS
https://coredns.io/blog/ [?]

Google DNS
[?]
(The Register article (see below) says Google is aware)

Infoblox
https://blogs.infoblox.com/ [?]

Quad9 DNS
https://www.quad9.net/news/blog/ [?]

Red Hat:
https://access.redhat.com/security/security-updates/cve [?]

News/Press

https://www.theregister.com/2024/02/13/dnssec_vulnerability_internet/

Validation:

Check to see if a server is doing DNSSEC validation (if not an open recursive resolver, you may need to query a zone the server is authoritative for):

# zone signed, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv example.net @8.8.8.8
; fully validated
example.net.            4437    IN      A       93.184.216.34
example.net.            4437    IN      RRSIG   A 13 2 86400 20240225232039 20240204162038 18113 example.net. 94G2PRXins1G9ntfklvCq2mvcgqjB0z9FqQXp77lD/wXR4J3D67ceih1 yNgsYYqlIAOoWKXUekux6Zq9aIwszQ==

# zone unsigned, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv google.com @8.8.8.8
; unsigned answer
google.com.             100     IN      A       142.250.69.206

Exploits:

(none yet known / public, but multiple sources describe as "trivial")

#keytrap #nsec3 #CVE202350387 #CVE202350868 #CVE_2023_50387 #CVE_2023_50868
#dns #dnssec

##
tychotithonus@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-13T22:51:51.000Z ##

I have two posts about the new multi-implementation DNSSEC validation DoS vulnerabilities CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap") and CVE-2023-50868 (the NSEC3 vuln):

  • The big summary post (more editing - your client may notify you about each edit, which may be a feature):

https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111924626712765292

  • The post you're reading (low editing, minimal noise, but you might want to check the big post occasionally for updates).

#keytrap #nsec3 #CVE202350387 #CVE202350868 #CVE_2023_50387 #CVE_2023_50868
#dns #dnssec

##
tychotithonus@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-13T14:24:29.000Z ##

(living doc, updated regularly - if you prefer a low-edit post to boost, use https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111926621712441626)

Looks like DNS-OARC coordinated fixes in advance, but I don't see a centralized analysis, other than this announcement from the team who discovered KeyTrap:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap
(Details may be still partially embargoed until patching ramps up)?

Analysis:

DoS of all major DNS servers at the implementation level. Servers are also clients; not clear to me if endpoint clients are vulnerable, but servers clearly are. Exploitation described as 'trivial'. Both are CVSS 7.5. DNS is a rich ransom target - but some resolver setups don't even validate DNSSEC.

"In 2012 the vulnerability made its way into the implementation requirements for DNSSEC validation, standards RFC 6781 and RFC 6840" (per ATHENE)

Per the Unbound writeup, both vulns require query to a malicious zone (which is probably not hard to trigger, for any DNSSEC-enabled client or server).

Resolution: patch (recommended); disable DNSSEC validation (discouraged, but can buy you time / mitigate active DoS)

Fixes mitigate the exhaustion by putting caps on validation activities. These caps appear to have been missing from most implementations.

Details:

Two DNSSEC DoS CVEs:

CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap"): "DNSSEC verification complexity can be exploited to exhaust CPU resources and stall DNS resolvers" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125

(KeyTrap was discovered by ATHENE - their press release here has very important detail:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap)

CVE-2023-50868: "NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

MITRE links (CVEs reserved, no details yet):
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50387
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50868

Vulmon queries:
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50387
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50868

Patch status:

ISC BIND (patched - vuln since 2000?):
https://fosstodon.org/@iscdotorg/111924416653890048
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50387
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50868
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125
(note: posts say "Versions prior to 9.11.37 were not assessed." but also have a range of affected versions starting at 9.0.0 - typo?)

Unbound (patched - vuln since Aug 2007):
https://nlnetlabs.nl/news/2024/Feb/13/unbound-1.19.1-released/
https://nlnetlabs.nl/downloads/unbound/CVE-2023-50387_CVE-2023-50868.txt
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/126

dnsmasq (patched - 2.90 has fix):
https://thekelleys.org.uk/dnsmasq/CHANGELOG
https://lists.thekelleys.org.uk/pipermail/dnsmasq-discuss/2024q1/017430.html

Pi-Hole (uses dnsmasq - fixes in beta)
https://pi-hole.net/blog/2024/02/13/fixing-two-new-dnssec-vulnerabilities/

PowerDNS (patched - all versions affected):
https://blog.powerdns.com/2024/02/13/powerdns-recursor-4-8-6-4-9-3-5-0-2-released
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13781
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13784

OS status:

FreeBSD:
https://cgit.freebsd.org/ports/commit/?id=58e048cad653819eebf91af5840e4b00f155bb1b

Ubuntu:
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50387
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50868
https://ubuntu.com/security/notices/USN-6633-1

Windows (Server, DNS Role):
https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2023-50387

Package status:

BIND:
https://repology.org/project/bind/versions

dnsmasq:
https://repology.org/project/dnsmasq/versions

Unbound:
https://repology.org/project/unbound/versions

Non-coverage: (no mentions known yet)

Akamai
https://www.akamai.com/blog [?]

AWS
[?]

Azure (Microsoft Server DNS?)
[?]

Cisco Umbrella:
https://umbrella.cisco.com/blog [?]

Cloudflare
https://blog.cloudflare.com/ [?]

CoreDNS
https://coredns.io/blog/ [?]

Google DNS
[?]
(The Register article (see below) says Google is aware)

Infoblox
https://blogs.infoblox.com/ [?]

Quad9 DNS
https://www.quad9.net/news/blog/ [?]

Red Hat:
https://access.redhat.com/security/security-updates/cve [?]

News/Press

https://www.theregister.com/2024/02/13/dnssec_vulnerability_internet/

Validation:

Check to see if a server is doing DNSSEC validation (if not an open recursive resolver, you may need to query a zone the server is authoritative for):

# zone signed, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv example.net @8.8.8.8
; fully validated
example.net.            4437    IN      A       93.184.216.34
example.net.            4437    IN      RRSIG   A 13 2 86400 20240225232039 20240204162038 18113 example.net. 94G2PRXins1G9ntfklvCq2mvcgqjB0z9FqQXp77lD/wXR4J3D67ceih1 yNgsYYqlIAOoWKXUekux6Zq9aIwszQ==

# zone unsigned, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv google.com @8.8.8.8
; unsigned answer
google.com.             100     IN      A       142.250.69.206

Exploits:

(none yet known / public, but multiple sources describe as "trivial")

https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap

https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap

tychotithonus at 2024-02-13T14:24:29.911Z ##

(living doc, updated regularly - if you prefer a low-edit post to boost, use https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111926621712441626)

Looks like DNS-OARC coordinated fixes in advance, but I don't see a centralized analysis, other than this announcement from the team who discovered KeyTrap:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap
(Details may be still partially embargoed until patching ramps up)?

Analysis:

DoS of all major DNS servers at the implementation level. Servers are also clients; not clear to me if endpoint clients are vulnerable, but servers clearly are. Exploitation described as 'trivial'. Both are CVSS 7.5. DNS is a rich ransom target - but some resolver setups don't even validate DNSSEC.

"In 2012 the vulnerability made its way into the implementation requirements for DNSSEC validation, standards RFC 6781 and RFC 6840" (per ATHENE)

Per the Unbound writeup, both vulns require query to a malicious zone (which is probably not hard to trigger, for any DNSSEC-enabled client or server).

Resolution: patch (recommended); disable DNSSEC validation (discouraged, but can buy you time / mitigate active DoS)

Fixes mitigate the exhaustion by putting caps on validation activities. These caps appear to have been missing from most implementations.

Details:

Two DNSSEC DoS CVEs:

CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap"): "DNSSEC verification complexity can be exploited to exhaust CPU resources and stall DNS resolvers" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125

(KeyTrap was discovered by ATHENE - their press release here has very important detail:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap)

CVE-2023-50868: "NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

MITRE links (CVEs reserved, no details yet):
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50387
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50868

Vulmon queries:
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50387
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50868

Patch status:

ISC BIND (patched - vuln since 2000?):
https://fosstodon.org/@iscdotorg/111924416653890048
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50387
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50868
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125
(note: posts say "Versions prior to 9.11.37 were not assessed." but also have a range of affected versions starting at 9.0.0 - typo?)

Unbound (patched - vuln since Aug 2007):
https://nlnetlabs.nl/news/2024/Feb/13/unbound-1.19.1-released/
https://nlnetlabs.nl/downloads/unbound/CVE-2023-50387_CVE-2023-50868.txt
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/126

dnsmasq (patched - 2.90 has fix):
https://thekelleys.org.uk/dnsmasq/CHANGELOG
https://lists.thekelleys.org.uk/pipermail/dnsmasq-discuss/2024q1/017430.html

Pi-Hole (uses dnsmasq - fixes in beta)
https://pi-hole.net/blog/2024/02/13/fixing-two-new-dnssec-vulnerabilities/

PowerDNS (patched - all versions affected):
https://blog.powerdns.com/2024/02/13/powerdns-recursor-4-8-6-4-9-3-5-0-2-released
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13781
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13784

OS status:

FreeBSD:
https://cgit.freebsd.org/ports/commit/?id=58e048cad653819eebf91af5840e4b00f155bb1b

Ubuntu:
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50387
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50868
https://ubuntu.com/security/notices/USN-6633-1

Windows (Server, DNS Role):
https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2023-50387

Package status:

BIND:
https://repology.org/project/bind/versions

dnsmasq:
https://repology.org/project/dnsmasq/versions

Unbound:
https://repology.org/project/unbound/versions

Non-coverage: (no mentions known yet)

Akamai
https://www.akamai.com/blog [?]

AWS
[?]

Azure (Microsoft Server DNS?)
[?]

Cisco Umbrella:
https://umbrella.cisco.com/blog [?]

Cloudflare
https://blog.cloudflare.com/ [?]

CoreDNS
https://coredns.io/blog/ [?]

Google DNS
[?]
(The Register article (see below) says Google is aware)

Infoblox
https://blogs.infoblox.com/ [?]

Quad9 DNS
https://www.quad9.net/news/blog/ [?]

Red Hat:
https://access.redhat.com/security/security-updates/cve [?]

News/Press

https://www.theregister.com/2024/02/13/dnssec_vulnerability_internet/

Validation:

Check to see if a server is doing DNSSEC validation (if not an open recursive resolver, you may need to query a zone the server is authoritative for):

# zone signed, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv example.net @8.8.8.8
; fully validated
example.net.            4437    IN      A       93.184.216.34
example.net.            4437    IN      RRSIG   A 13 2 86400 20240225232039 20240204162038 18113 example.net. 94G2PRXins1G9ntfklvCq2mvcgqjB0z9FqQXp77lD/wXR4J3D67ceih1 yNgsYYqlIAOoWKXUekux6Zq9aIwszQ==

# zone unsigned, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv google.com @8.8.8.8
; unsigned answer
google.com.             100     IN      A       142.250.69.206

Exploits:

(none yet known / public, but multiple sources describe as "trivial")

#keytrap #nsec3 #CVE202350387 #CVE202350868 #CVE_2023_50387 #CVE_2023_50868
#dns #dnssec

##
tychotithonus@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-13T22:51:51.000Z ##

I have two posts about the new multi-implementation DNSSEC validation DoS vulnerabilities CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap") and CVE-2023-50868 (the NSEC3 vuln):

  • The big summary post (more editing - your client may notify you about each edit, which may be a feature):

https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111924626712765292

  • The post you're reading (low editing, minimal noise, but you might want to check the big post occasionally for updates).

#keytrap #nsec3 #CVE202350387 #CVE202350868 #CVE_2023_50387 #CVE_2023_50868
#dns #dnssec

##
tychotithonus@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-13T14:24:29.000Z ##

(living doc, updated regularly - if you prefer a low-edit post to boost, use https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111926621712441626)

Looks like DNS-OARC coordinated fixes in advance, but I don't see a centralized analysis, other than this announcement from the team who discovered KeyTrap:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap
(Details may be still partially embargoed until patching ramps up)?

Analysis:

DoS of all major DNS servers at the implementation level. Servers are also clients; not clear to me if endpoint clients are vulnerable, but servers clearly are. Exploitation described as 'trivial'. Both are CVSS 7.5. DNS is a rich ransom target - but some resolver setups don't even validate DNSSEC.

"In 2012 the vulnerability made its way into the implementation requirements for DNSSEC validation, standards RFC 6781 and RFC 6840" (per ATHENE)

Per the Unbound writeup, both vulns require query to a malicious zone (which is probably not hard to trigger, for any DNSSEC-enabled client or server).

Resolution: patch (recommended); disable DNSSEC validation (discouraged, but can buy you time / mitigate active DoS)

Fixes mitigate the exhaustion by putting caps on validation activities. These caps appear to have been missing from most implementations.

Details:

Two DNSSEC DoS CVEs:

CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap"): "DNSSEC verification complexity can be exploited to exhaust CPU resources and stall DNS resolvers" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125

(KeyTrap was discovered by ATHENE - their press release here has very important detail:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap)

CVE-2023-50868: "NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

MITRE links (CVEs reserved, no details yet):
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50387

Validation:

Check to see if a server is doing DNSSEC validation (if not an open recursive resolver, you may need to query a zone the server is authoritative for):

# zone signed, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv example.net @8.8.8.8
; fully validated
example.net.            4437    IN      A       93.184.216.34
example.net.            4437    IN      RRSIG   A 13 2 86400 20240225232039 20240204162038 18113 example.net. 94G2PRXins1G9ntfklvCq2mvcgqjB0z9FqQXp77lD/wXR4J3D67ceih1 yNgsYYqlIAOoWKXUekux6Zq9aIwszQ==

# zone unsigned, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv google.com @8.8.8.8
; unsigned answer
google.com.             100     IN      A       142.250.69.206

##
ne1for23@betweenthelions.link at 2024-02-13T22:50:00.000Z ##

#dnsmasq version 2.90 released with fixes for CVE-2023-50387 and CVE-2023-50868.

The issue is only a security vulnerability if #DNSSEC is enabled.

#SysAdmin #DNS
https://lists.thekelleys.org.uk/pipermail/dnsmasq-discuss/2024q1/017430.html

##
thedarktangent@defcon.social at 2024-02-13T16:55:15.000Z ##

Jumping on an airplane just as the #Bind “KeyTrap” vulnerability drops.
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50387

The good news is we split our recursive resolvers from our authoritative servers, a distinction that has saved us in the past and saves us here as well. Recursive is done by a mega provider we trust, Quad9. (Thanks @woody) 😂

##
ne1for23@betweenthelions.link at 2024-02-13T22:50:00.000Z ##

#dnsmasq version 2.90 released with fixes for CVE-2023-50387 and CVE-2023-50868.

The issue is only a security vulnerability if #DNSSEC is enabled.

#SysAdmin #DNS
https://lists.thekelleys.org.uk/pipermail/dnsmasq-discuss/2024q1/017430.html

##
alienghic@octodon.social at 2024-02-13T22:48:47.000Z ##

I just saw from https://mstdn.social/@rysiek/111926520750227620 that there's some exploits to do a denial of service attack on DNSSEC validators

The #debian security tracker pages for the #keytrap vulnerabilities are
https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2023-50387
https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2023-50868

The good news is we split our recursive resolvers from our authoritative servers, a distinction that has saved us in the past and saves us here as well. Recursive is done by a mega provider we trust, Quad9. (Thanks @woody) 😂

##
tychotithonus at 2024-02-13T14:24:29.911Z ##

(living doc, updated regularly - if you prefer a low-edit post to boost, use https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111926621712441626)

Looks like DNS-OARC coordinated fixes in advance, but I don't see a centralized analysis, other than this announcement from the team who discovered KeyTrap:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap
(Details may be still partially embargoed until patching ramps up)?

Analysis:

DoS of all major DNS servers at the implementation level. Servers are also clients; not clear to me if endpoint clients are vulnerable, but servers clearly are. Exploitation described as 'trivial'. Both are CVSS 7.5. DNS is a rich ransom target - but some resolver setups don't even validate DNSSEC.

"In 2012 the vulnerability made its way into the implementation requirements for DNSSEC validation, standards RFC 6781 and RFC 6840" (per ATHENE)

Per the Unbound writeup, both vulns require query to a malicious zone (which is probably not hard to trigger, for any DNSSEC-enabled client or server).

Resolution: patch (recommended); disable DNSSEC validation (discouraged, but can buy you time / mitigate active DoS)

Fixes mitigate the exhaustion by putting caps on validation activities. These caps appear to have been missing from most implementations.

Details:

Two DNSSEC DoS CVEs:

CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap"): "DNSSEC verification complexity can be exploited to exhaust CPU resources and stall DNS resolvers" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125

(KeyTrap was discovered by ATHENE - their press release here has very important detail:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap)

CVE-2023-50868: "NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

MITRE links (CVEs reserved, no details yet):
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50387
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50868

Vulmon queries:
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50387
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50868

Patch status:

ISC BIND (patched - vuln since 2000?):
https://fosstodon.org/@iscdotorg/111924416653890048
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50387
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50868
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125
(note: posts say "Versions prior to 9.11.37 were not assessed." but also have a range of affected versions starting at 9.0.0 - typo?)

https://nlnetlabs.nl/news/2024/Feb/13/unbound-1.19.1-released/
https://nlnetlabs.nl/downloads/unbound/CVE-2023-50387_CVE-2023-50868.txt

https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13781

; fully validated
example.net.            4437    IN      A       93.184.216.34
example.net.            4437    IN      RRSIG   A 13 2 86400 20240225232039 20240204162038 18113 example.net. 94G2PRXins1G9ntfklvCq2mvcgqjB0z9FqQXp77lD/wXR4J3D67ceih1 yNgsYYqlIAOoWKXUekux6Zq9aIwszQ==

Unbound (patched - vuln since Aug 2007):
https://nlnetlabs.nl/news/2024/Feb/13/unbound-1.19.1-released/
https://nlnetlabs.nl/downloads/unbound/CVE-2023-50387_CVE-2023-50868.txt
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/126

dnsmasq (patched - 2.90 has fix):
https://thekelleys.org.uk/dnsmasq/CHANGELOG
https://lists.thekelleys.org.uk/pipermail/dnsmasq-discuss/2024q1/017430.html

Pi-Hole (uses dnsmasq - fixes in beta)
https://pi-hole.net/blog/2024/02/13/fixing-two-new-dnssec-vulnerabilities/

PowerDNS (patched - all versions affected):
https://blog.powerdns.com/2024/02/13/powerdns-recursor-4-8-6-4-9-3-5-0-2-released
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13781
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13784

OS status:

FreeBSD:
https://cgit.freebsd.org/ports/commit/?id=58e048cad653819eebf91af5840e4b00f155bb1b

Ubuntu:
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50387
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50868
https://ubuntu.com/security/notices/USN-6633-1

Windows (Server, DNS Role):
https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2023-50387

Package status:

BIND:
https://repology.org/project/bind/versions

dnsmasq:
https://repology.org/project/dnsmasq/versions

Unbound:
https://repology.org/project/unbound/versions

Non-coverage: (no mentions known yet)

Akamai
https://www.akamai.com/blog [?]

AWS
[?]

Azure (Microsoft Server DNS?)
[?]

Cisco Umbrella:
https://umbrella.cisco.com/blog [?]

Cloudflare
https://blog.cloudflare.com/ [?]

CoreDNS
https://coredns.io/blog/ [?]

Google DNS
[?]
(The Register article (see below) says Google is aware)

Infoblox
https://blogs.infoblox.com/ [?]

Quad9 DNS
https://www.quad9.net/news/blog/ [?]

Red Hat:
https://access.redhat.com/security/security-updates/cve [?]

News/Press

https://www.theregister.com/2024/02/13/dnssec_vulnerability_internet/

Validation:

Check to see if a server is doing DNSSEC validation (if not an open recursive resolver, you may need to query a zone the server is authoritative for):

# zone signed, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv example.net @8.8.8.8
; fully validated
example.net.            4437    IN      A       93.184.216.34
example.net.            4437    IN      RRSIG   A 13 2 86400 20240225232039 20240204162038 18113 example.net. 94G2PRXins1G9ntfklvCq2mvcgqjB0z9FqQXp77lD/wXR4J3D67ceih1 yNgsYYqlIAOoWKXUekux6Zq9aIwszQ==

# zone unsigned, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv google.com @8.8.8.8
; unsigned answer
google.com.             100     IN      A       142.250.69.206

Exploits:

(none yet known / public, but multiple sources describe as "trivial")

#keytrap #nsec3 #CVE202350387 #CVE202350868 #CVE_2023_50387 #CVE_2023_50868
#dns #dnssec

##
tychotithonus at 2024-02-13T22:51:51.189Z ##

I have two posts about the new multi-implementation DNSSEC validation DoS vulnerabilities CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap") and CVE-2023-50868 (the NSEC3 vuln):

  • The big summary post (more editing - your client may notify you about each edit, which may be a feature):

https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111924626712765292

  • The post you're reading (low editing, minimal noise, but you might want to check the big post occasionally for updates).

#keytrap #nsec3 #CVE202350387 #CVE202350868 #CVE_2023_50387 #CVE_2023_50868
#dns #dnssec

##
tychotithonus at 2024-02-13T14:24:29.911Z ##

(living doc, updated regularly - if you prefer a low-edit post to boost, use https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111926621712441626)

Looks like DNS-OARC coordinated fixes in advance, but I don't see a centralized analysis, other than this announcement from the team who discovered KeyTrap:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap
(Details may be still partially embargoed until patching ramps up)?

Analysis:

DoS of all major DNS servers at the implementation level. Servers are also clients; not clear to me if endpoint clients are vulnerable, but servers clearly are. Exploitation described as 'trivial'. Both are CVSS 7.5. DNS is a rich ransom target - but some resolver setups don't even validate DNSSEC.

"In 2012 the vulnerability made its way into the implementation requirements for DNSSEC validation, standards RFC 6781 and RFC 6840" (per ATHENE)

Per the Unbound writeup, both vulns require query to a malicious zone (which is probably not hard to trigger, for any DNSSEC-enabled client or server).

Resolution: patch (recommended); disable DNSSEC validation (discouraged, but can buy you time / mitigate active DoS)

Fixes mitigate the exhaustion by putting caps on validation activities. These caps appear to have been missing from most implementations.

Details:

Two DNSSEC DoS CVEs:

CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap"): "DNSSEC verification complexity can be exploited to exhaust CPU resources and stall DNS resolvers" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125

(KeyTrap was discovered by ATHENE - their press release here has very important detail:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap)

CVE-2023-50868: "NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

MITRE links (CVEs reserved, no details yet):
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50387
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50868

Vulmon queries:
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50387
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50868

Patch status:

ISC BIND (patched - vuln since 2000?):
https://fosstodon.org/@iscdotorg/111924416653890048
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50387
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50868
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125
(note: posts say "Versions prior to 9.11.37 were not assessed." but also have a range of affected versions starting at 9.0.0 - typo?)

Unbound (patched - vuln since Aug 2007):
https://nlnetlabs.nl/news/2024/Feb/13/unbound-1.19.1-released/
https://nlnetlabs.nl/downloads/unbound/CVE-2023-50387_CVE-2023-50868.txt
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/126

dnsmasq (patched - 2.90 has fix):
https://thekelleys.org.uk/dnsmasq/CHANGELOG
https://lists.thekelleys.org.uk/pipermail/dnsmasq-discuss/2024q1/017430.html

Pi-Hole (uses dnsmasq - fixes in beta)
https://pi-hole.net/blog/2024/02/13/fixing-two-new-dnssec-vulnerabilities/

PowerDNS (patched - all versions affected):
https://blog.powerdns.com/2024/02/13/powerdns-recursor-4-8-6-4-9-3-5-0-2-released
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13781
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13784

OS status:

FreeBSD:
https://cgit.freebsd.org/ports/commit/?id=58e048cad653819eebf91af5840e4b00f155bb1b

Ubuntu:
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50387
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50868
https://ubuntu.com/security/notices/USN-6633-1

Windows (Server, DNS Role):
https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2023-50387

Package status:

BIND:
https://repology.org/project/bind/versions

dnsmasq:
https://repology.org/project/dnsmasq/versions

Unbound:
https://repology.org/project/unbound/versions

Non-coverage: (no mentions known yet)

Akamai
https://www.akamai.com/blog [?]

AWS
[?]

Azure (Microsoft Server DNS?)
[?]

Cisco Umbrella:
https://umbrella.cisco.com/blog [?]

Cloudflare
https://blog.cloudflare.com/ [?]

CoreDNS
https://coredns.io/blog/ [?]

Google DNS
[?]
(The Register article (see below) says Google is aware)

Infoblox
https://blogs.infoblox.com/ [?]

Quad9 DNS
https://www.quad9.net/news/blog/ [?]

Red Hat:
https://access.redhat.com/security/security-updates/cve [?]

News/Press

https://www.theregister.com/2024/02/13/dnssec_vulnerability_internet/

Validation:

Check to see if a server is doing DNSSEC validation (if not an open recursive resolver, you may need to query a zone the server is authoritative for):

# zone signed, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv example.net @8.8.8.8
; fully validated
example.net.            4437    IN      A       93.184.216.34
example.net.            4437    IN      RRSIG   A 13 2 86400 20240225232039 20240204162038 18113 example.net. 94G2PRXins1G9ntfklvCq2mvcgqjB0z9FqQXp77lD/wXR4J3D67ceih1 yNgsYYqlIAOoWKXUekux6Zq9aIwszQ==

# zone unsigned, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv google.com @8.8.8.8
; unsigned answer
google.com.             100     IN      A       142.250.69.206

Exploits:

(none yet known / public, but multiple sources describe as "trivial")

Looks like DNS-OARC coordinated fixes in advance, but I don't see a centralized analysis, other than this announcement from the team who discovered KeyTrap:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap
(Details may be still partially embargoed until patching ramps up)?

Both are CVSS 7.5. DNS is a rich ransom target - but some resolver setups don't even validate DNSSEC.

"In 2012 the vulnerability made its way into the implementation requirements for DNSSEC validation, standards RFC 6781 and RFC 6840" (per ATHENE)

Per the Unbound writeup, both vulns require query to a malicious zone (which is probably not hard to trigger, for any DNSSEC-enabled client or server).

Both are CVSS 7.5. DNS is a rich ransom target - but some resolver setups don't even validate DNSSEC.

"In 2012 the vulnerability made its way into the implementation requirements for DNSSEC validation, standards RFC 6781 and RFC 6840" (per ATHENE)

Per the Unbound writeup, both vulns require query to a malicious zone (which is probably not hard to trigger, for any DNSSEC-enabled client or server).

Resolution: patch (recommended); disable DNSSEC validation (discouraged, but can buy you time / mitigate active DoS)

Fixes mitigate the exhaustion by putting caps on validation activities. These caps appear to have been missing from most implementations.

Details:

Two DNSSEC DoS CVEs:

CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap"): "DNSSEC verification complexity can be exploited to exhaust CPU resources and stall DNS resolvers" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125

(KeyTrap was discovered by ATHENE - their press release here has very important detail:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap)

CVE-2023-50868: "NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

MITRE links (CVEs reserved, no details yet):
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50387
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50868

Vulmon queries:
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50387
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50868

Patch status:

ISC BIND (patched - vuln since 2000?):
https://fosstodon.org/@iscdotorg/111924416653890048
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50387
https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50868
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125
(note: posts say "Versions prior to 9.11.37 were not assessed." but also have a range of affected versions starting at 9.0.0 - typo?)

Unbound (patched - vuln since Aug 2007):
https://nlnetlabs.nl/news/2024/Feb/13/unbound-1.19.1-released/
https://nlnetlabs.nl/downloads/unbound/CVE-2023-50387_CVE-2023-50868.txt
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/126

dnsmasq (patched - 2.90 has fix):
https://thekelleys.org.uk/dnsmasq/CHANGELOG
https://lists.thekelleys.org.uk/pipermail/dnsmasq-discuss/2024q1/017430.html

Pi-Hole (uses dnsmasq - fixes in beta)
https://pi-hole.net/blog/2024/02/13/fixing-two-new-dnssec-vulnerabilities/

PowerDNS (patched - all versions affected):
https://blog.powerdns.com/2024/02/13/powerdns-recursor-4-8-6-4-9-3-5-0-2-released
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13781
https://github.com/PowerDNS/pdns/pull/13784

OS status:

FreeBSD:
https://cgit.freebsd.org/ports/commit/?id=58e048cad653819eebf91af5840e4b00f155bb1b

Ubuntu:
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50387
https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-50868
https://ubuntu.com/security/notices/USN-6633-1

Windows (Server, DNS Role):
https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2023-50387

Package status:

BIND:
https://repology.org/project/bind/versions

dnsmasq:
https://repology.org/project/dnsmasq/versions

Unbound:
https://repology.org/project/unbound/versions

Non-coverage: (no mentions known yet)

Akamai
https://www.akamai.com/blog [?]

[?]

Azure (Microsoft Server DNS?)
[?]

Cisco Umbrella:
https://umbrella.cisco.com/blog [?]

https://blog.cloudflare.com/ [?]

https://coredns.io/blog/ [?]

Google DNS
[?]
(The Register article (see below) says Google is aware)

Infoblox
https://blogs.infoblox.com/ [?]

Quad9 DNS
https://www.quad9.net/news/blog/ [?]

Red Hat:
https://access.redhat.com/security/security-updates/cve [?]

News/Press

https://www.theregister.com/2024/02/13/dnssec_vulnerability_internet/

Validation:

Check to see if a server is doing DNSSEC validation (if not an open recursive resolver, you may need to query a zone the server is authoritative for):

# zone signed, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv example.net @8.8.8.8
; fully validated
example.net.            4437    IN      A       93.184.216.34
example.net.            4437    IN      RRSIG   A 13 2 86400 20240225232039 20240204162038 18113 example.net. 94G2PRXins1G9ntfklvCq2mvcgqjB0z9FqQXp77lD/wXR4J3D67ceih1 yNgsYYqlIAOoWKXUekux6Zq9aIwszQ==

# zone unsigned, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv google.com @8.8.8.8
; unsigned answer
google.com.             100     IN      A       142.250.69.206

Exploits:

(none yet known / public, but multiple sources describe as "trivial")

#keytrap #nsec3 #CVE202350387 #CVE202350868 #CVE_2023_50387 #CVE_2023_50868
#dns #dnssec

##
tychotithonus at 2024-02-13T22:51:51.189Z ##

I have two posts about the new multi-implementation DNSSEC validation DoS vulnerabilities CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap") and CVE-2023-50868 (the NSEC3 vuln):

  • The big summary post (more editing - your client may notify you about each edit, which may be a feature):

https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111924626712765292

  • The post you're reading (low editing, minimal noise, but you might want to check the big post occasionally for updates).

##
tychotithonus at 2024-02-13T14:24:29.911Z ##

(living doc, updated regularly - if you prefer a low-edit post to boost, use https://infosec.exchange/@tychotithonus/111926621712441626)

Looks like DNS-OARC coordinated fixes in advance, but I don't see a centralized analysis, other than this announcement from the team who discovered KeyTrap:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap
(Details may be still partially embargoed until patching ramps up)?

Analysis:

DoS of all major DNS servers at the implementation level. Servers are also clients; not clear to me if endpoint clients are vulnerable, but servers clearly are. Exploitation described as 'trivial'. Both are CVSS 7.5. DNS is a rich ransom target - but some resolver setups don't even validate DNSSEC.

"In 2012 the vulnerability made its way into the implementation requirements for DNSSEC validation, standards RFC 6781 and RFC 6840" (per ATHENE)

Per the Unbound writeup, both vulns require query to a malicious zone (which is probably not hard to trigger, for any DNSSEC-enabled client or server).

Resolution: patch (recommended); disable DNSSEC validation (discouraged, but can buy you time / mitigate active DoS)

Fixes mitigate the exhaustion by putting caps on validation activities. These caps appear to have been missing from most implementations.

Details:

Two DNSSEC DoS CVEs:

CVE-2023-50387 ("KeyTrap"): "DNSSEC verification complexity can be exploited to exhaust CPU resources and stall DNS resolvers" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H
https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2024/q1/125

(KeyTrap was discovered by ATHENE - their press release here has very important detail:
https://www.athene-center.de/en/news/press/key-trap)

CVE-2023-50868: "NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU" (CVSS 7.5)
CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

MITRE links (CVEs reserved, no details yet):
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50387
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2023-50868

Vulmon queries:
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50387
https://vulmon.com/searchpage?q=CVE-2023-50868

Patch status:

ISC BIND (patched - vuln since 2000?):

https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2023-50868

Validation:

Check to see if a server is doing DNSSEC validation (if not an open recursive resolver, you may need to query a zone the server is authoritative for):

# zone signed, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv example.net @8.8.8.8
; fully validated
example.net.            4437    IN      A       93.184.216.34
example.net.            4437    IN      RRSIG   A 13 2 86400 20240225232039 20240204162038 18113 example.net. 94G2PRXins1G9ntfklvCq2mvcgqjB0z9FqQXp77lD/wXR4J3D67ceih1 yNgsYYqlIAOoWKXUekux6Zq9aIwszQ==

# zone unsigned, server DNSSEC-enabled:
$ delv google.com @8.8.8.8
; unsigned answer
google.com.             100     IN      A       142.250.69.206

neurovagrant@masto.deoan.org at 2024-02-06T15:53:06.000Z ##

"Google on Monday announced patches for 46 vulnerabilities in Android, including a critical-severity bug leading to remote code execution.

The flaw, tracked as CVE-2024-0031 and impacting Android Open Source Project (AOSP) versions 11, 12, 12L, 13, and 14, was identified in the platform’s System component. "

KyanHexagon@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-01T02:22:20.000Z ##

https://snyk.io/blog/leaky-vessels-docker-runc-container-breakout-vulnerabilities/

Snyk researchers identified four vulnerabilities (CVE-2024-21626, CVE-2024-2365, CVE-2024-23653, and CVE-2024-23652) in core container infrastructure components that allow an attacker to escape the containers and gain unauthorized access to the underlying host operating system. Synk has released two tools that serve as reference implementations for detecting exploit attempts. They also recommend watching for patches from container build and runtime vendors.

##
